question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

Which one of the following could be the schedule of the students' reports?
A) Mon. morning: Helen; Mon. afternoon: Robert Tues. morning: Olivia; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Lenore; Wed. afternoon: Kyle
B) Mon. morning: Irving; Mon. afternoon: Olivia Tues. morning: Helen; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Nina; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
C) Mon. morning: Lenore; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: George; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Robert; Wed. afternoon: Irving
D) Mon. morning: Nina; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: Robert; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Olivia; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
E) Mon. morning: Olivia; Mon. afternoon: Nina Tues. morning: Irving; Tues. afternoon: Helen Wed. morning: Kyle; Wed. afternoon: George
full_output:
Do not output anything else.
        - The choices appear as given above.
        -

<cot>
Check each option one by one.

Option A:
Mon. morning Helen; afternoon Robert.
Tues. morning Olivia; afternoon Irving.
Wed. morning Lenore (only) and afternoon Kyle (only).

Check conditions:
1 Tuesday has George? No.
2 Afternoon reports: Robert (morning), Irving (afternoon) - both morning.
3 Nina? No.

No violations. However, check if all conditions are met.

But wait: Condition 1 says Tuesday is only day George can report. Here, George does not report, so that's fine.

But also check if exactly six students give reports: Helen, Robert, Olivia (mornoing), Irving, Lenoure, Kyle. So six students. But wait: Nina is not included. So that's fine. So option A might be valid. But check other conditions.

Wait, check condition 4 about Nina. Nina is NOT giving a report here, so no problem.

But check condition about George: Tuesday has no George, so it's okay.

But then check condition: "Tuesday is the ONLY day on Which George can Give a report." So if George doesn't give a presentation, that's fine as long as he doesn't present on Tuesday. But condition doesn't say he must present. So it's fine.

Wait: But wait, the question says "exactly six will ... give individual reports" So if Nina is excluded, that's six students: Helen (mor), Robert (af), Olivia (mo), Irving(af), Lenore(mo), Kyle(af). So six. So Option A is valid. However note that condition 5 says "Neither Olivia nor R. can give afternoon report." In Option A, Olivia is morning, Robert is afternoon. So condition 6: "If Nina gives report, next day must have Helen and Irvin reports." But Nina does not give report, condition 7 is not triggered. So all conditions satisfied.

But let's check Option A carefully.

Wait check condition "exacty six students" are giving reports. In OptionA, six students are giving: Helen morning, R. afternoon, Olivia morning, Irvin afternoon, Lenour morning, Kyle afternoon. Nina and George are not giving. But the question said "exact six will ..." So that's correct.

But condition 8: "if Nina gives, then next day has Helen and I. But Nina doesn't give, so that condition is not applicable."

Condition 1 holds: Tuesday no George. So yes, Option A might work. But let's check other options.

Option B:
Mon: Irving (mor) and Olivia (af).
Tues: Helen(mor) and Kyle( af).
Wed: Nina(mor), Lenour(af).

Check:
1: Tuesday: George? Not present. Good.
2: Afternoon: Olivia (but Olivia is afternoon, which condition 9 says neither Olivia nor Rob can give af. So this violates condition. So B is invalid.

Option C:
Mon morning:Lenore; afternoon: H.E. (Helen)
Tues morning:George; afternoon Kyle.
Wed morning:Robert; afternoon Irvin.

Check:
Condition 2 says afternoon: No afternoon reports by Olivia or Robert. Here afternoon reports: Len, Helen (af) is Helen, Kyle (af). But Kyle is not Olivia or R. So fine.
Condition 4? Nina is absent, so okay.
Condition1: George is on Tues morning, which satisfies condition1 (only Tuesday allowed). So good.
Condition2: H. and I are on Wed morning and af. But Wednesday has two reports: morning Robert, afternoon I. So Helen and Ira are not both on Wed. But if Nina gives on Wed, then Helen and IR must both be on Wed? Wait, condition: if Nina's presentation is on Wed then Helen & I must both present on Wed (because Nina's day is Wed, so next day is Thursday, but we only have three days. Wait, re-read condition: 
"If Nina gives ... then on next day, Helen and irving must both g. reports." Wait, the condition says: "Nina gives a presentation then on NEXT day, both Helen and Ivan must give presentations." But in this schedule, Nina does NOT give a present. Because Nina is on W. morning. So the condition is triggered only if Nina presents. But here Nina does present. Wait: Option C: Nina gives Wed morning. Then next day (Thursday) must have both Helen & Irving. But we only go Wed. So check condition carefully:

Condition: " If Nina's present. then on THE NEXT day (i.e., Thursday) both Helen AND Irvin must give reports." However, our schedule only has three days: Monday, Tuesday and Wed. Thursday is not available. So if in Option C, Nina gives presentation on Wednesday morning, then the next day's reports (Thursday's) must include Helen and Irvine. But Thursday does not exist. So that violates condition

question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If George, Nina, and Robert give reports and they do so on different days from one another, which one of the following could be true?
A) Helen gives a report on Wednesday.
B) Nina gives a report on Monday.
C) Nina gives a report on Tuesday.
D) Olivia gives a report on Monday.
E) Robert gives a report on Wednesday.

question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If Kyle gives the afternoon report on Tuesday, and Helen gives the afternoon report on Wednesday, which one of the following could be the list of the students who give the morning reports on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, respectively?
A) Irving, Lenore, and Nina
B) Lenore, George, and Irving
C) Nina, Irving, and Lenore
D) Robert, George, and Irving
E) Robert, Irving, and Lenore
